result.execSummary:
The defendant Genevieve S. Thornberry was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Causing Mental Harm to Child, a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.04(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
THE DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS SHALL DEDUCT RESTITUTION AND ALL OTHER COURT OBLIGATIONS AT THE RATE OF 25% OF ALL MONIES RECEIVED WHILE INCARCERATED.
-------------------------------------
*AMENDMENT 2-9-2016 - To reflect Ten (10) days of sentence credit.

superMiscConds.notes:
Pay restitution in the amount of $420.00 and restitution surcharge. 
------------------------------------

Pay court costs and DOC supervision fees.   If the defendant is discharged from Extended Supervision with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment may be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.
------------------------------------

No contact with minors without Agent approval. 
------------------------------------
**AMENDMENT 8/3/2018 - Defendant may have no unsupervised contact with juveniles, other than incidental, and other than with her own daughter, A.M.L. dob 12/24/2004.
--------------------------------------------

Attend, participate and complete all assessments, evaluations and treatment including but not limited to sex offender treatment.
------------------------------------
Register as a sex offender for (15) fifteen years. 
------------------------------------
Provide biological specimen to state crime lab for DNA analysis, and pay DNA analysis surcharge.
------------------------------------
*AMENDMENT 10/30/2019 - Judgment of Conviction amended to reflect requirement of Sex Offender registry is eliminated. 
-----------------------------------

from the JOC, Amended JOC and Order Denying Motion for Postconviction Relief
Denying Postconviction Motion

Postconviction Motion Hearing before the Honorable Phillip Koss on August 3, 2018
Court Reporter Sandy Elderbrook
No objection by ADA Johnson to proposed Order

10:01 am  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  
ADA Haley Jo Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Deft Genevieve S. Thornberry in court, in custody with Atty Hans Koesser.  
Matter is before Court on defense Motion for Postconviction Relief asking that Court not order sex offender registration.  
State has filed a response which Atty Koesser has reviewed.  
10:02 am  Argument by Atty Koesser in support of Motion.  
10:06 am  Response by Atty Koesser to Court's question.  
10:11 am  Court asks parties how this issue came to Judge Reddy's attention later?  
10:11 am  Response by Atty Johnson.  
10:12 am  Further argument by Atty Koesser.  
10:15 am  Response by Atty Johnson.  
10:17 am  Continued argument by both Attys.  
10:20 am  Response by Court.  Continued argument by attys
10:27 am  Court makes ruling.  There was an agreement to be free to argue and on November 5th Atty Duquette reports that they have an agreement and specifically says that they are agreeing to the conditions of probation.  The PSI does make statement with regard to sex offender registration.  When there is no specific exercise of discretion at sentencing it is because Judge Reddy has relied upon the parties agreement which includes that.  Court thinks Judge is justified to rely on that.  He then exercises discretion, that although he included it, he realizes by January that she is not agreement with it and at that point the Judge needs to exercise discretion and imposes the sex offender registration.  Court makes further record.  Defense to prepare an Order.  
10:31 am  Atty Johnson makes further record.  Atty Koesser has no further record to make.  
10:32 am  Court has colloquy with Ms. Thornberry.  
10:32 am  Discussion concerning no contact condition of probation.  Court will order JOC to be modified to state:  Defendant may have no unsupervised contact with juveniles, other than incidental, and other than with her own daughter, A.M.L., dob 12/24/2004.  
10:34 am  Court in recess.

**TRANSCRIPT FILED 8/10/18: COURT REPORTER SANDY ELDERBROOK**

records.descr: Notice of intent to pursue post-conviction relief

records.addlTxt:
9:04 a.m.  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  Haley Jo Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Genevieve S. Thornberry in court, in custody with attorney James B. Duquette.  Matter is before the Court to discuss the period of sex offender registration.   When defendant was sentenced, the Court did not indicate the length of time for sex offender registration.  The PSI writer had recommended sex offender registration.  The Court did review the string of e-mails between the Attorneys concerning this.  With this conviction not being a "sex offense" under Sec. 301.45, the issue of sex offender registration was not discussed at the time of sentencing.  Discussion between Court and Attorneys as to whether the parties had an agreement to adopt the recommendations of the PSI.  Court will consider this argument as to whether sex offender registration should occur, and if so, for what length of time.  9:09 a.m.  Argument by Attorney Johnson.  9:13 a.m.  Argument by Attorney Duquette.  Court believes we need to review Sec. 301.45 (1d)(b).  Continued argument by Attorney Duquette.  Court notes there does appear to be a conflict beween Sec. 973.048(1m)(a) and 301.45(1d)(b).  Response by Attorney Johnson as to the distinction between the statutes.  Court believes it can justify the difference between "shall" and "may".  Response by Attorney Duquette.  Court finds 973.048.(1m) is "discretionary" as to sex offender registration and 301.45(1d)(b) is "shall" - mandatory sex offender registration.  Argument by Attorney Duquette as to whether or the not sex offender registration should be ordered by the Court.  Further argument by Attorney Johnson.  9:33 a.m.  Court takes a recess to consider this matter and will return at 9:50 a.m. to render a decision.  9:48 a.m.  Court in session.  Attorney Duquette misspoke during his argument and wishes to make a further record.  Court makes findings as to each factor set forth in the statute.  This crime was sexual motivated conduct and sex offender registration is in the interests of public protection.  Court requires sex offender registration by the defendant for 15 years.  9:53 a.m. Court in recess.
